origination.corpname: University of Michigan. News and Information Services. Podcasts.

did.unittitle: News and Information Services (University of Michigan) Podcasts 2006-2010
did.abstract: Audio podcasts on various topics, often relating to faculty research or university and current events, usually featuring University of Michigan faculty or staff. .

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The podcasts were received from the News and Information Service 285 in several accession beginning in 2010.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The records are open without restriction.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, News and Information Services (University of Michigan) Podcasts, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The University of Michigan News and Information Services is responsible for preparing press releases about university activities, providing photographs and film of university functions and scholarly announcements to the various news media, and publishing and distributing the University Record and Michigan Today.

News and Information Services has undergone several name and organizational changes throughout its history. Beginning in 1897, the university had a department of information services that performed many of the functions of a press office. In 1930, following the installation of President Alexander G. Ruthven, the university created a News Dissemination Service (often called the University of Michigan News Service). Over the ensuing decades the name of the organization has changed from News Service to Information Services, and finally to News and Information Services. The organizational home of the unit has also changed as it moved from an independent unit to part of the Bureau of Alumni Relations, and later part of the Office of University Relations. It currently is part of the Vice President for Communications.
News and Information Service began producing podcasts in 2006.

scopecontent.p: The Podcasts series contains audio podcasts produced by the News and Information Service starting in 2006. The podcasts were mainly disseminated through the News and Information Website, and primarily include stories about research and creative works by University of Michigan faculty. Other topics include the expansion of and events at the University of Michigan Museum of Art, the leadership vision of the University's president, and visiting speakers.

The podcasts are now hosted as downloadable mp3 files in Deep Blue, the University of Michigan's institutional repository. The listing for each podcast includes the title, date of recording, the filename, length (in minutes and seconds) the mime-type of the file and, in most cases, an abstract of the podcast's content and the speakers. The podcasts are organized chronologically by date of recording or first release.

did.abstract: President Mary Sue Coleman's remarks to graduates at Winter Commencement, Dec. 19, 2004, in Michigan Stadium. Speakers: Mary Sue Coleman.
President Mary Sue Coleman's remarks to graduates at Winter Commencement, Dec. 18, 2005, in Michigan Stadium. Speakers: Mary Sue Coleman.
President Mary Sue Coleman's remarks to graduates at Spring Commencement, April 29 2006, in Michigan Stadium. Speakers: Mary Sue Coleman.

President Mary Sue Coleman delivered the keynote opening address of the 2006 conference of the Professional and Scholarly Publishing Division of the Association of American Publishers in Washington, D.C., Feb. 6, 2006. Speakers: Mary Sue Coleman.
President Mary Sue Coleman at the National Press Club in Washington, D.C., March 7, 2006. Speakers: Mary Sue Coleman.
President Mary Sue Coleman's remarks at her inauguration as the University of Michigan's 13th president. Speakers: Mary Sue Coleman.
President Mary Sue Coleman's remarks to graduates at Spring Commencement, April 30 2005, in Michigan Stadium. Speakers: Mary Sue Coleman.
Michael Traugott dicusses a survey done about opinions on the public use of cell phones. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Michael Traugott.

Cancer has rejuvenating stem cells, just like organs do. Sean Morrison's group has found a way to selectively identify and kill just the cancerous stem cells in mice with leukemia, leaving healthy blood-forming stem cells alone. Speakers: Karl Bates, Sean Morrison.

From "Xena: Warrior Princess" to "Judging Amy," television shows are redefining women in dramatic roles by telling diverse stories about their lives, a University of Michigan analysis shows. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Amanda Lotz.
U.S. executives engage in stock-option dating games to boost pay. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Nejat Seyhun.

University of Michigan Research Assistant Prof. Jennifer Glass says her research indicates years of tobacco use may dim the speed and accuracy of a person's thinking ability and bring down their IQ. Speakers: Roger Sutton, Jenifer Glass.

Stephen Weiss' research team was looking for a gene that affected the development of the circulatory system in mice. Quite by mistake, they found a 'molecular scissors' that loosens the collagen belt around fat cells, allowing them to expand. Speakers: Karl Bates, Stephen J. Weiss, M.D..
Bone loss actually starts before estrogen and the decline of estrogen levels, probably because of another hormone's activity. Speakers: Karl Bates, MaryFran R. Sowers.
Professor Dan Klionsky in the Life Science Institute believes that students can learn biology without books or lectures. Speakers: Karl Bates, Dan Klionsky.
University of Michigan public policy Prof. Sheldon Danziger discusses latest poverty trends. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Sheldon H. Danziger.
University of Michigan history Prof. Juan Cole discusses whether or not we are winning the fight against al-Qaeda. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Juan Cole.
University or Michigan Museum of Art (UMMA) Director James Steward discusses UMMA's expansion and renovation. Speakers: Frank Provenzano, James Steward.
Research by UM psychologists suggests that people commonly consider social categories when making decisions about who to hire, etc. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Stephen Garcia.
The University of Michigan is launching an interdisciplinary institute to increase the university's commitment to energy research. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Gary Was.
President Mary Sue Coleman's address to University of Michigan Faculty Senate Assembly, October 30, 2006. Speakers: Mary Sue Coleman.

In the year after a hurricane, tornado, terrorist attack or other natural or man-made disaster, 30-40 percent of adults who were directly affected may suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder. Speakers: Roger Sutton, Sandro Galea.
Interest in international adoptions has grown tremendously within the last two decades. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Leslie Hollingsworth.

did.unittitle: Why are Americans so bad at math? 2006-11-03
did.abstract: It's become common for Americans to laughingly say "oh well, I am no good at math so my child is not either." Could you imagine anyone saying those words about reading? Deborah Ball, a member of a White House panel on improving math instruction and dean of the U-M School of Education, talks about how Americans as a society got so far behind in math and what we need to do to get back to where we need to be. Why is it important to be proficient at math and how can we get there? Ball explains why. Speakers: Joe Serwach, Deborah Ball.

did.unittitle: Two Poems by Britta Ameel 06 MFA 2006-11-08
Two Poems by Britta Ameel 06 MFA 2006-11-08
The potential of nuclear power as a clean energy option 11/27/2006
did.abstract: Nuclear engineering and radiological sciences deals with the human application of subatomic particles with energies from fractions of an electron volt to millions of electron volt, and with the interactions of radiation with matter. Speakers: William Martin, William Martin.
Composers' work inspiration for dance performance that was be part of 2006-07 national tour. Speakers: Frank Provenzano, Christian Matjias.
Facial masculinity may serve as a visual cue in female mate choice, much as the tail of the male peacock signals females about male fitness to reproduce. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Daniel J. Kruger.

did.unittitle: Accreditation creates new steps for School of Dance 1/2/2007
did.abstract: DeYoung says, "Through our teaching and key collaborations around the University, we've proven that the dance is perhaps the most agile of all art forms, drawing on many disciplines, from the visual arts to science.". Speakers: Bill DeYoung, Bill DeYoung.

did.unittitle: Fortifying bridge from Ann Arbor to Detroit 2007-01-08
did.abstract: Dec. 5 trip is upclose look at potential impact of new site. Speakers: Frank Provenzano.

did.unittitle: Smoking rates higher among low-income African-Americans 2007-01-15
did.abstract: As overall smoking rates in the U.S. decline, the smoking rate among low-income African-Americans increases. Speakers: Jorge Delva, Jorge Delva.

Andrew Grogan-Kaylor says his new study indicates children who get high levels of intellectual stimulation at home, such as books and educational games, had parents who rarely used physical punishment. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Andrew Grogan-Kaylor.

did.unittitle: Time, money and who does the laundry 1/30/2007
did.abstract: Women and girls still spend more time than men and boys on housework. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow/Frank Stafford, Frank Stafford.

did.unittitle: Black History Month is still relevant today 2007-02-02
did.abstract: Percy Bates says it's important for society, especially young people, to know about the history of other races. While it's great that one month focuses on the contributions of African-Americans, he would like to see black history -- as well as the history of other ethnic groups -- taught year round. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Percy Bates.

did.unittitle: Nuclear power generates waste with special needs 2/12/2007
did.abstract: Nuclear engineering and radiological science Prof. William Martin outlines research projects in nuclear energy at the U-M and discusses how nuclear waste is to be disposed in the U.S. Speakers: Laura Bailey, William Martin.

U-M Research Professor Lloyd Johnston compares today's teens with teens of 33 years ago and everyone in between. His Monitoring the Future survey has surveyed more than 1 million teens since the study began in 1975 asking them about drug use, smoking, drinking and other habits every year. A Distinguished Research Scientist at U-M's Institute for Social Research, Johnston is principal investigator of the Monitoring the Future study. Speakers: Frank Provenzano, Lloyd Johnston.

University of Michigan researchers found that 3-year-old children exposed to two or more hours of TV a day were nearly three times more likely to be overweight than children who either watched or were in a room with a TV on for fewer than two hours a day,. Speakers: Roger Sutton, Julie Lumeng.

With participation and attendance increasing since the first exhibit 12 years ago, the Annual Exhibition of Art by Michigan Prisoners is making connections between prisoners and the community, and deconstructing stereotypes about those incarcerated. Speakers: Frank Provenzano, Prison Creative Arts Project.

University of Michigan professor Enoch Brater talks about playwright Arthur Miller as the University hosts a grand opening of the Arthur Miller Theatre, the only one in the world named after Miller. Speakers: Frank Provenzano, Enoch Brater.
McDonald is a veteran newspaper correspondent who has done several tours in Iraq and Afghanistan. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Mark McDonald.

did.unittitle: Are you "High Testosterone" and is that good? 4/9/2007
did.abstract: U-M psychology professor Oliver Schultheiss, who runs the Human Motivation and Affective Neuroscience Lab, talks about how hormones like testosterone impact human behavior. Schultheiss describes how to tell if you??Ÿ?¦Ÿ??re "high testosterone" and the pluses and minuses. Speakers: Joe Serwach, Oliver Schultheiss.
Joanne Nesbitt chronicles her walk through one of U-M's most popular cultural attractions. Speakers: Joanne Nesbitt.

This interdisciplinary effort will result in a 15-year perspective study that will not only lend insight into Latin America, but also should be applicable to further the understanding of substance use among all youths in the United States. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Jorge Delva.

did.unittitle: Improving the environment, creating economic opportunity 5/25/2007
did.abstract: Policy blueprint, Michigan at a Climate Crossroads Strategies for Guiding the State in a Carbon-Constrained World, presented to Michigan legislators on May 23 presents compelling case that time is at hand to reform state regulations. Speakers: Jim Erickson, Gregory Keoleian.

John Burkhardt, is a U-M professor of higher education and director of the National Forum on Higher Education for the Public Good. He also serves as a special assistant to the provost for University engagement and organized ``Challenges and Opportunities: Conversations about immigration and higher education. He talks about where the nation is on this major issue being debated in Congress. Speakers: Joe Serwach, John C. Burkhardt.

We talk to U-M astronomer John Monnier and graduate student Ming Zhao. They led an international team that combined light from four widely separated telescopes to produce the first picture showing surface details on a sun-like star beyond our solar system. It was a rapidly rotating, hot star called Altair. Speakers: Jim Erikson, John D. Monnier.
Michigan will be a poorer state over the next decade, but its universities and resources like the Great Lakes can help reverse its declining economy. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Donald Grimes.
People with diabetes who keep their blood sugar in check today will probably have a far lower chance of developing foot pain or other nerve damage tomorrow. Speakers: Roger Sutton, Eva Feldman.
Knowing the past sheds light on future possibilities. Speakers: Frank Provenzano, John C. Dann.

did.unittitle: Monitoring the Future 1: How it Began 8/3/2007
did.abstract: Every year since 1975, University of Michigan researcher Lloyd Johnston's team has conducted the Monitoring the Future study of 50,000 young Americans. In this first part of a multi-part interview, Johnston describes how the survey that has interviewed more than 1 million people all began. Speakers: Serwach, Lloyd Johnston.
Current UAW contract talks with U.S. automakers may be the most important in decades. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Bruce Belzowski.
discussion with professor about ACL injuries and research into these. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Riann Palmieri Smith.

Engineering professor Zoran Filipi believes plug-in hybrid electric vehicles will be common on the highways of tomorrow. He explains how they work and why they could help reduce greenhouse gases. Speakers: Nicole Casal Moore, Zoran Filipi.
Birches will likely drive out aspens in northern forests as carbon dioxide levels continue to mount in coming decades. Speakers: Jim Ericson, Donald Zak.

Jude and Hensler discovered that newly hatched round gobies leave their lake bottom homes and swim to the surface at night, a nocturnal migration that increases the chances that large numbers of hatchlings will get sucked into the ballast tanks of Great Lakes freighters. Speakers: Jim Erickson, David Jude.

Julio Frenk, former minister of health of Mexico, and current counsel to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation talks about disaster preparedness at School of Public Health symposium on Sept. 11, 2007. Speakers: laura bailey, na.

did.unittitle: Renowned pianist to visit U-M students Oct. 4 9/21/2007
did.abstract: U-M Department of Music offers upclose interaction with preeminent pianist. Speakers: Provenzano, Steven Whiting.

In the last years of his life, Bo Schembechler passed his leadership secrets to writer John U. Bacon. The result is a book, "Bo's Lasting Lessons: The Legendary Coach Teaches the Timeless Fundamentals of Leadership" that offers leaders both penetrating insight ("You can't lead people unless you like people") and practical advice ("Recruit for character"). Bacon discusses Bo's leadership style, and describes what it was like to work for the notoriously demanding coach. Speakers: John Lofy, John U. Bacon.

did.unittitle: The high costs of financial services for the poor 2007-10-04
did.abstract: Low-income households in the United States often lack access to bank accounts and face high costs for conducting basic financial transactions through check cashers and other alternative financial service providers. Law professor Michael Barr says these families find it more difficult to save and plan financially for the future. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Michael Barr.
UM curators transform eBay into art gallery. Speakers: Frank Provenzano, Rebekah Modrak.

did.unittitle: Schmoozing is good for the brain 10/29/2007
did.abstract: Shooting the breeze for just 10 minutes boosts mental performance. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Oscar Ybarra.
Men looked more favorably toward smoking when they saw movie character John McCane (Die Hard) smoke. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Sonya Dal Cin.
Listen to Prof. Aiello explain how we protect ourselves against MRSA, and what the emergence of this in schools really means. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Allison Aiello.

Michigan's economy has seen seven years of great plenty, followed by seven years of economic famine---but, unfortunately, it's not over yet, say University of Michigan economists. Speakers: Wadley, George Fulton.

To cope with dwindling freshwater supplies, U-M professor Walter Weber discusses treating wastewater for drinking. He talks about his ideas for better water management and how we could extract energy from toilet water. Speakers: Nicole Casal Moore, Walter Weber.

U-M Psychology Chair Terri Lee is an expert on sleep and the circadian rhythms we all live by. Changing your natural rhythms -- particularly during adolescence -- can cause major problems, she warns. Speakers: Serwach, Theresa Lee.

did.unittitle: Do you know what your children are watching? 12/7/2007
did.abstract:
Watching media violence significantly increases the risk that a viewer or video game player will behave aggressively in both the short and long term, according to a University of Michigan study published today in a special issue of the Journal of Adolescent Health. The study, by L. Rowell Huesmann, reviews more than half a century of research on the impact of exposure to violence in television, movies, video games and on the Internet.
"The research clearly shows that exposure to virtual violence increases the risk that both children and adults will behave aggressively," said Huesmann, the Amos N. Tversky Collegiate Professor of Communication Studies and Psychology, and a senior research scientist at the U-M Institute for Social Research (ISR). Speakers: Jared Wadley, L. Rowell Huesmann.
Susan Collins, dean of the Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy, discusses issues raised at the Dec. 3 White House jobs summit. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Susan M. Collins.

Women who exercise for a body shape motive, such as wanting to lose weight or to become toned, spend about 40 percent less time exercising than women who exercise for motives not related to achieving a certain body shape or weight. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Michelle Segar.
Gershoff says that we overestimate how much. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Andrew Gershoff.

did.unittitle: Enhancing shower and bathtub safety for the aged 1/6/2008
did.abstract: Healthcare professionals should help prevent bathing accidents, not just treat people after they have had a fall in the bathroom. Speakers: Roger Sutton, Susan Murphy.
We often form opinions and make decisions based on a lone, repetitive voice that we mistake for a chorus. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Stephen Garcia.
This research is about how couple who resolve conflict live longer than those who do not. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Ernest Harburg, Emeritus.

Analysis of data over 13 years with more than 800 adults shows that we're likely to see our spouses as more irritating and demanding as we age, while we are likely to see our relationships with children and friends more positively. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Kira Birditt.

did.unittitle: "I'm 25 and I still live with my parents" 2008-01-23
did.abstract: It takes young people longer to complete their schooling, settle into steady employment, and delay marriage and childbearing, according to new findings. Thus, it's become socially acceptable living with parents as an adult. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Sheldon Danziger.

did.unittitle: Success elevates profile of U-M screenwriters 2008-02-09
did.abstract: Impressive list of U-M alumni making impact in Hollywood. Speakers: Frank Provenzano, Jim Burnstein.

Robert Van Order of the Ross School of Business says America's faltering economy and overextended borrowers aren't the only causes of the subprime crisis -- lenders and investors are also to blame. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Robert Van Order.
Helping others is good for the helper. Speakers: Roger Sutton, Neil Krause.

did.unittitle: Kids who feel safe act more safely 3/4/2008
did.abstract: Urban kids who feel safe delay gratification, behave less dangerously. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Daniel Kruger.

Hillary Clinton says the media coverage is pro-Barack Obama. This has forced some news organizations to take another look at their presidential election coverage, as well as take a closer look at Obama and his background. Bucy discusses the media coverage. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Erik Bucy.
In Goldstein's view, the power of an irreverent image, cartoon or illustration can appeal to the most people---and leave an indelible impression. Speakers: Frank Provenzano, Robert Goldstein.
University of Michigan finance professor explains what and why the Federal Reserve intervened in the Bear Stearns banking crisis. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Amiyatosh Purnanandam.
Victor Yanovsky, research scientist at U-M, discusses the laser beam that sets a world record for intensity. Speakers: Nicole Casal Moore, Victor Yanovsky.
Americans may not socialize with colleagues as much as workers in other countries do, but they enjoy it when they do. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Aleksandra Kacperczyk.

did.unittitle: Online Q and A forums hit the mainstream 4/18/2008
did.abstract: Online question and answer forums are as old as the Internet, but they're reaching the mainstream and making the web more human, say two researchers who have just completed a large-scale study of Yahoo Answers. Speakers: Nicole Casal Moore, Mark Ackerman and Lada Adamic.

The University of Michigan Law School will open a new clinic in January that will assist prisoners convicted in cases where biological evidence like DNA doesn't exist. This Innocence Clinic is unique because other "Innocence Clinics" mainly handle cases involving DNA evidence. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Bridget McCormack.
MMPEI is working with other organizations on campus to develop a tool to help scientists and engineers project whether new cleaner technologies will take hold. Speakers: Nicole Casal Moore, Gary Was.

Researchers from the University of Michigan Health System and the Veterans Administration Ann Arbor Healthcare System say sedentary and overweight people with type two diabetes who participated in a walking study were more motivated to walk if they wore pedometers and consulted a Web site that tracked physicals activity. Speakers: Roger Sutton, Caroline Richardson.
The last few primaries for the presidential candidates concludes soon, but many questions remain in the Democratic Party's two-person race. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Vincent Hutchings.
Regardless of one's stance on climate change, it makes economic sense for businesses and consumers to take climate-related action. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Andrew Hoffman.

University of Michigan President Mary Sue Coleman and her fellow University Research Corridor presidents from Michigan State University and Wayne State University joined forces at the Mackinac Policy Conference. During the conference at the island's famous Grand Hotel, we asked the president about her vision for the URC, an alliance of Michigan's three research universities. Speakers: Joe Serwach, Mary Sue Coleman.
Professor Perry Samson recently returned from a storm chasing trip with students. He talks about where, why and what it was like. Speakers: Nicole Casal Moore, Perry Samson.
Voters still focus on the first name on the ticket, not the VP choice. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Kenneth Kollman.
ISR researcher Carey Wexler Sherman is looking for participants in a new study of older remarried caregivers. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Carey Wexler Sherman.

Two student members of the U-M solar car team discuss the upcoming North American Solar Challenge and compare it to the World Solar Challenge, which took place in October. Spencer Bailey, who was in the car when it crashed in 2007, discusses the crash. Speakers: Nicole Casal Moore, Solar Car Team.

Sports fans know the story of Jackie Robinson, whose debut in 1947 ended an era of Jim Crow in the major leagues. As the Brooklyn Dodgers' president, U-M Law School graduate Branch Rickey signed Robinson. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Richard Friedman.
Mothers relive traumatic experience of sexual abuse during their childbearing years. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Mickey Sperlich.

Fifteen students will find ways to build bridges between the intellectual pursuits of an academic life and the mystic forces that for millennia shaped everyday life in India. Speakers: Frank Provenzano, Stephen Rush.
U-M Vice President for Research Steve Forrest, an expert on energy research, discusses the opportunities to developing alternative energy research. Speakers: Joe Serwach, Steve Forrest.

Elliot Soloway has developed educational software for cell phones that allows them to be used in the classroom as personal computers. He discusses technology in the classroom. Speakers: Nicole Casal Moore, Elliot Soloway.

Conventions no longer accomplish what they used to, such as shaping key messages and policies. They have turned out to be extravagant parties still covered by the media. U-M professor Michael Traugott talks about what is accomplished at conventions today and the significant moments that can define the remaining months until the November elections. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Michael Traugott.

The environment is playing a much larger role in everyday diseases. What are environmental toxicants and why do we know they contribute to health problems? University of Michigan professor Howard Hu explains. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Howard Hu.
Anxious college freshmen can relax. No matter who will be sharing their dorm room, they have the power to make the relationship better, say U-M researchers. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Amy Canevello.

Elizabeth Moje has spent years following and studying adolescents in southwest Detroit, to discover why many low income students struggle with reading. She's found many answers on how they read and interact and how to better teach the teachers. Speakers: Joe Serwach, Elizabeth Birr Moje.
Young women look to their favorite female TV characters as role models for behavior and appearance. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Dara Greenwood.
New research shows that the best way to move ahead emotionally is to analyze one's feelings from a psychologically distanced perspective. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Ethan Kross.

The current turmoil in America's financial markets is the worst since the Great Depression and Wall Street's response has made things worse. Regulation will make things better. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Sreedhar Barath.
Global aging and why should we care?. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Mary Haan.

Now that Congress has passed the $700 billion bailout law, the American economy should begin to recover, but regulations are needed to prevent it from happening again. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, M.P. Narayanan.

As the presidential campaigns wind down to their final weeks before Nov. 4th's election day, the number of negative television and radio ads seems to be increasing. University of Michigan professor Arthur Lupia and doctoral student Yanna Krupnikov say voters typically do not like negative ads, especially as some are still deciding which candidate should replace Bush in the Oval Office. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Arthur Lupia.

Wayne Baker, a Ross School professor and sociologist at the Institute for Social Research, discusses public reaction to the financial bailout and hot topics in the election. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Wayne Baker.
The results suggest that masks and handwashing can reduce the spread of symptoms by as much as 50 percent. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Allison Aiello.

In a sense, Nov. 4 is judgment day. Election officials know if their efforts to improve the voting process is successful. Pollsters will learn if their reports were accurate. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Michael Traugott.

Americans are eager for President-elect Barack Obama to assume his position in the White. But will his leadership and governing style entail? Can he meet expectations? What does his election mean for the business world?. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, D. Scott DeRue.
Describes how women should decide whether to take insulin, and what it means if she has existing heart risk factors. Speakers: Laura Bailey, MaryFran Sowers.
Retail marketing professor Aradhna Krishna suggests four policies to prevent store stampedes. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Aradhna Krishna.
Professor Daniel Kruger looks to evolution to explain why we overspend. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Daniel Kruger.
Researchers discover a way to use gene therapy to slow and reverse the progression of periodontal disease. Speakers: Laura Bailey, William Giannobile.
Chamberlin talks about politicians and business executives acting unethically. Speakers: Jared Wadley, John Chamberlin.
UMTRI's Bruce Belzowski provides overview of what GM, Ford, Chrysler, Honda and Toyota are featuring at this year's Detroit auto show. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Bruce Belzowski.
Joycelyn Elders, 15th Surgeon General under then President Bill Clinton, discusses current pressing public health issues of today. Speakers: laura bailey, Joycelyn Elders.
Social psychologist Richard Nisbett discusses the impact of environment, including schools and culture, on the development of intelligence. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Richard E. Nisbett.
Morrow talks about changes in foreign policy under the Obama administration. Speakers: Jared Wadley, James Morrow.

Collaborative energy-research partnerships will enable the University of Michigan to prosper while helping to diversify and revive the state's economy, according to Vice President for Research Stephen Forrest. Speakers: Jim Erickson, Stephen Forrest.
New research shows that playing violent video games and watching violent moves make people less empathic and sensitive to the suffering of others. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Brad Bushman.
New research shows that playing violent video games and watching violent moves make people less empathic and sensitive to the suffering of others. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Brad Bushman.

By 2011, the nation's computer data centers will consume more power than 8 million average U.S. households. A new strategy cuts down on their energy waste by putting servers to sleep when they're not in use. Speakers: Nicole Casal Moore, Thomas Wenisch.
The days of the cozy relationship between executives and boards are gone. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Noel Tichy.
The European Union and the United States must work together to solve the world's economic crisis. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Jan Svejnar.
A new University of Michigan analysis finds that physical punishment does not improve children's behavior in the long term. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Elizabeth Gershoff.

Human trafficking is the second largest criminal activity in the world, generating billions of dollars annually. The new law clinic opens fall 2009 to help victims regain their lives. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Bridgette Carr.

The new advocacy clinic will provide legal representation and social work services to low-income families to prevent unnecessary placement and prolonged stay of children in foster care. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Vivek Sankaran.

did.unittitle: Obese children twice as likely to have diabetes 4/19/2007
did.abstract: "Among school-aged children, obese children have a greater than twofold chance of having diabetes, compared with children of normal weight," Dr. Joyce Lee says. "The large number of children with diabetes in the U.S., and the potential for increasing numbers of children developing diabetes with the obesity epidemic, has serious implications for how these children will receive appropriate health care now and as they grow into adulthood.". Speakers: Roger Sutton, Joyce Lee.

Massive layoffs, budget cuts, closures. The news is bad enough for workers and executives who lose their jobs. But for those still employed, keeping morale high can be challenging. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Gretchen Spreitzer.

Astronomy professor Ted Bergin will use the Herschel Space Observatory to search for the building blocks of life in the clouds of gas and dust around young stars. His research could give new insights into how life began on Earth. Speakers: Nicole Casal Moore, Ted Bergin.

These days, many people feel stressed by the high unemployment rates, foreclosures and personal income. U-M professor Melvin McInnis talks about what's happening and offers tips to cope with depression. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Melvin McInnis.

U-M President Mary Sue Coleman will join Michigan State University President Lou Anna Simon and Wayne State University President Jay Noren at Mackinac Island May 28 to release a new University Research Corridor report. Coleman answers the question ``What is the URC in this one minute podcast. Speakers: Joe Serwach.

New research shows that it's common for adult children and their parents to annoy each other. The research identifies common sources of irritation, and how parents and adult kids cope. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Kira Birditt.
When young men are scarce, they're more likely to play the field than to propose. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Daniel Kruger.

JoLynn Montgomery of the School of Public Health defines pandemic, and provides some simple steps people can take to protect themselves and other from flu symptoms. Speakers: Laura Bailey, JoLynn Montgomery.

More than 37 million people are considered poor. U-M expert Sheldon Danziger says the Obama Administration could have policies in place to lower the poverty rate in the next few years. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Sheldon Danziger.
Researcher Scott Roberts discusses the debate over direct to consumer genetic testing. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Scott Roberts.

Forty years after the first lunar landing, astronaut and associate dean in the College of Engineering Tony England discusses the significance of Apollo 11 and the future of U.S. space travel and science. Speakers: Nicole Casal Moore, Tony England.
Professor Scott McLean discusses how sports injury prevention training programs could differ in the future. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Scott McLean.

did.unittitle: The road ahead for the Fed 2009-08-07
did.abstract: Assistant professor John Ciorciari talks about what is ahead for the Federal Reserve, whose actions have raised concerns about inflation. Speakers: Jared Wadley, John Ciorciari.

Do you hoard (hang on to everything), leaving huge stacks of stuff whenever you're not sure if something is trash or might be needed in the future? Or are you a Spartan who throws everything away? U-M Assistant Psychology Professor Stephanie Preston explains what motivates both and what each trait has to do with traits related to survival, planning, anxiety, fear and a need to boost your status. Speakers: Joe Serwach, Stephanie Preston.

University of Michigan researchers have identified a gene that acts as a master switch to control obesity in mice. The finding could lead to treatments for obesity, diabetes and complications associated with those disorders. Speakers: Jim Erickson, Alan Saltiel.
Mark Rosentraub discusses why Chicago lost the Olympic bid and if it's possible to make money hosting the Olympics. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Mark Rosentraub.

The Ford School's Douglas A. Brook says security comes from not only military power, but also the strength of diplomatic and humanitarian functions of government and non-governmental agents acting in a concerted fashion. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Douglas A. Brook.
U-M professor Linda Lim discusses the U.S. decision to impose a tariff on Chinese tires and how an all-out trade war can be averted. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Linda Lim.

A discussion with professor Richard Rood, who will attend the COP-15 climate change meeting, about the meeting's significance and the role of higher ed in the debate. Speakers: Nicole Casal Moore, Richard Rood.
University of Michigan School of Public Health Dean Kenneth Warner discusses the benefits of the new smoking ban passed by the Michigan Senate and House. Speakers: Laura Lessnau, Kenneth Warner.
Professor Louis Burgio talks about how the holiday season brings the holiday blues, especially among the elderly. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Louis Burgio.

Professor Tyler Shumway examines ways in which individual investors impacted and reacted to the economic meltdown. His assessment shatters some popular myths and attitudes. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Tyler Shumway.
Law professor Julian Davis Mortenson discusses the legal issues facing the alleged airplane bomber. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Julian Davis Mortenson.

Public companies in Norway have been negatively effected by a recent law requiring corporate boards to have female membership of at least 40 percent---but not because of gender. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Amy Dittmar.

did.unittitle: Students resolve conflict, bias through small group interactions 2/29/2008
did.abstract: If students understand what causes conflicts and assumptions about others different from them, they are able to adapt later in life, according to a new University of Michigan study. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Charles Garvin.
Professor Susan Douglas says women have not gained full equality, which is the opposite of what media images tend to show. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Susan Douglas.

A conversation with Tamas Gombosi, chair of the Department of Atmospheric, Oceanic and Space Sciences, about what the Cassini spacecraft has taught scientists about Saturn's space environment. Speakers: Nicole Casal Moore, Tamas Gombosi.

Michigan's local government leaders expressed an alarming lack of trust in state government leaders in Lansing and significant dissatisfaction with their job performance. This distrust raises questions about the ability of state-level officials to produce policy solutions that depend on local implementation. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Tom Ivacko.

Joanne Pohl, a professor of nursing at the School of Nursing, served on a health care panel that issued sweeping recommendations that included increasing the number of primary-care providers, which include general-practice physicians, nurse practitioners and physician assistants. Speakers: Jim Erickson, Joanne Pohl.
Dr. Paul Green of Driver Interface Group at the University of Michigan discusses banning texting while driving in Michigan. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Paul Green.
Research shows that today's college students are less empathic than students were before 2000. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Ed O'Brien.
When men outnumber women, the women tend to marry younger and men engage in riskier, more aggressive behavior. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Daniel Kruger.

did.unittitle: Pro sports is a global force 6/8/2010
did.abstract: Sports has become a global force. Soccer, however, is not as popular in the United States, which prefers football, baseball, basketball and hockey. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Andrei S. Markovits.
Interview with University of Michigan assistant professor Scott Campbell about the usage of cellphones by teens. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Scott Campbell.
U-M alumni Sharon Shattuck talks about her short documentary Parasites: A User's Guide that she shot at the U-M Biological Station. Speakers: Laura Lessnau, Sharon Shattuck.
Research reveals significant differences in grieving among Black, white and Hispanic caregivers of Alzheimer's patients. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, James McNally.

did.unittitle: A shift in Made in China 7/22/2010
did.abstract: China expert Mary Gallagher talks about the impact of migrant workers going on strike to increase wage and to improve working conditions in Chinese manufacturing companies. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Mary E. Gallagher.
U-M research suggests a new tactic that parents can use to increase the odds children will actually do their homework without engaging in all-out battles. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Daphna Oyserman.

Sheldon Danziger, director of the National Poverty Center at U-M, says poverty levels will exceed 15 percent -- which translates to more than 45 million people. Speakers: Jared Wadley, Sheldon Danziger.
Workplace wellness plans work best when they include all workers, not just those who are already sick. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Dee Edington.
Interview with Oleg Tsodikov about what this discovery means in the fight to cure tuberculosis. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Oleg Tsodikov.
Friendly conversations improve mental functioning, but competitive encounters do not. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Oscar Ybarra.
The debate continues over how much vitamin D we really need. New research shows that lack of Vitamin D in kids is linked to weight gain. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Eduardo Vilamor.
In a new study, U-M business professor M. S. Krishnan says that cloud computing helps small businesses. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, M. S. Krishnan.

did.unittitle: Which city do you live in? 11/9/2010
did.abstract: Christopher Peterson's new study shows that some cities are high on heart strengths and some rank high on head strengths. Speakers: Laura Lessnau, Christopher Peterson.
Rather than negotiate better terms with creditors or ask for help from family and friends, elder Americans prefer to file for bankruptcy protection. Speakers: Jared Wadley, John A. E. Pottow.
New study from University of Michigan School of Public Health shows that common chemicals may adversely affect our immune system. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Erin Clayton.
Professor William Lovejoy explains that relationships of modern manufacturers with large, complex supply chains are constantly evolving. Speakers: William Lovejoy.
Sunil Kapila explains that the use of 3-D x-ray in orthodontics and pediatric dentistry should be limited. Speakers: Laura Bailey, Sunil Kapila.
New U-M study shows how fight styles affect marriage. Speakers: Diane Swanbrow, Kira Birditt.

A growing number of companies are learning that implementing sustainable business practices isn't just good for the environment - it can also be good for the bottom line. Speakers: Bernie DeGroat, Andrew Hoffman.
